title: Founding of Văn Lang State
titleVietnamese: Dựng nước Văn Lang
description: According to Vietnamese legend, Lạc Long Quân and Âu Cơ's son became the first Hùng King, founding the Văn Lang state. This marks the beginning of Vietnamese statehood and the legendary Hùng Kings dynasty that would rule for over 2,600 years.
descriptionVietnamese: Theo truyền thuyết Việt Nam, con trai của Lạc Long Quân và Âu Cơ trở thành vua Hùng đầu tiên, dựng nên nước Văn Lang. Đây là khởi đầu của quốc gia Việt Nam.
shortDescription: Legendary founding of the first Vietnamese state under the Hùng Kings
significance: Establishment of the first Vietnamese state and foundation of Vietnamese national identity. The legend of Lạc Long Quân and Âu Cơ giving birth to 100 sons became the origin myth of the Vietnamese people.

title: Development of Đông Sơn Culture
titleVietnamese: Phát triển văn hóa Đông Sơn
description: The Đông Sơn culture represents the Bronze Age civilization of northern Vietnam, famous for sophisticated bronze drums, tools, and weapons. These bronze drums feature intricate geometric patterns and scenes depicting daily life, boats, and ceremonies. This culture spread throughout Southeast Asia and represents the peak of Bronze Age technology in the region.
descriptionVietnamese: Văn hóa Đông Sơn đại diện cho nền văn minh thời đại đồ đồng ở miền Bắc Việt Nam, nổi tiếng với những chiếc trống đồng tinh xảo.
shortDescription: Bronze Age civilization known for sophisticated bronze drums and metalworking
significance: Peak of Bronze Age technology in Southeast Asia. Đông Sơn bronze drums became iconic symbols of Vietnamese culture and demonstrate advanced metalworking skills. The culture's influence spread across maritime Southeast Asia.

The festival continues to modern day as a national holiday.

title: Construction of Cổ Loa Citadel
titleVietnamese: Xây dựng thành Cổ Loa
description: An Dương Vương constructed the massive Cổ Loa fortress, one of the most impressive ancient fortifications in Southeast Asia. The citadel features three concentric layers of earthen ramparts spanning approximately 8 kilometers, with sophisticated moats and water defenses. It served as the capital of Âu Lạc kingdom and housed an estimated population of 20,000-30,000 at its peak.

significance: Advanced military architecture demonstrating sophisticated urban planning and engineering. One of the earliest spiral-shaped citadels in the world. Symbol of Âu Lạc kingdom's power and technological advancement.

title: Trưng Sisters' Rebellion
titleVietnamese: Khởi nghĩa Hai Bà Trưng
description: Trưng Trắc and Trưng Nhị led a successful uprising against Chinese Han Dynasty rule after the Chinese governor Tô Định murdered Trưng Trắc's husband, Thi Sách. The sisters raised an army, liberated 65 citadels across northern Vietnam, and briefly restored Vietnamese independence. Trưng Trắc was proclaimed queen and ruled from 40-43 AD. The rebellion was ultimately crushed by Han General Ma Yuan, and both sisters committed suicide by jumping into the Hát River rather than surrender.

title: Lý Bôn's Uprising - Vạn Xuân Kingdom
titleVietnamese: Khởi nghĩa Lý Bôn - Nước Vạn Xuân

significance: First successful long-term independence from China after over 600 years of domination. Proved Vietnamese could establish and maintain independent state. Sparked cultural renaissance and laid groundwork for eventual permanent independence.

title: Third Mongol Invasion - Battle of Bạch Đằng River (1288)
titleVietnamese: Trận Bạch Đằng - Đại thắng quân Mông Cổ lần thứ ba (1288)

title: Gulf of Tonkin Incident - US Entry into War
titleVietnamese: Sự kiện Vịnh Bắc Bộ - Mỹ tham chiến
description: The Gulf of Tonkin Incident involved alleged attacks on US Navy destroyers by North Vietnamese patrol boats. The first attack (August 2) did occur, but the second attack (August 4) likely never happened - it was probably false radar readings. Nevertheless, President Johnson used these incidents to obtain Congressional authorization for full-scale war without declaring war. This marked America's massive military escalation in Vietnam.

shortDescription: Disputed naval incidents gave US Congress authorization for full-scale war
significance: Triggered massive US military escalation. Second 'attack' probably never happened. Congress passed Gulf of Tonkin Resolution giving Johnson war powers without declaring war. Led to deployment of 500,000+ US troops. Showed how US entered war based on questionable intelligence. Resolution not repealed until 1971. Many historians view it as manufactured justification for pre-planned escalation.

description: During Tết (Lunar New Year), North Vietnamese and Việt Cộng forces launched coordinated surprise attacks on over 100 cities and towns throughout South Vietnam, including the US Embassy in Saigon. title: Paris Peace Accords - US Withdrawal
titleVietnamese: Hiệp định Paris - Mỹ rút quân
description: After years of negotiations, the Paris Peace Accords ended direct US military involvement in Vietnam. The agreement called for ceasefire, return of American POWs, and US withdrawal within 60 days. However, it left North Vietnamese troops in South Vietnam and the political situation unresolved. significance: Ended direct US combat role in Vietnam. Secured release of American POWs. Called for ceasefire (widely violated). Left 200,000 North Vietnamese troops in South. South Vietnam government retained but weakened. US continued aid but no combat support. Kissinger and Lê Đức Thọ won Nobel Peace Prize. 'Peace' was illusion - fighting continued. South Vietnam fell 2 years later.

description: The Communist Party's 6th National Congress launched Đổi Mới (Renovation) reforms, marking Vietnam's transition from centrally-planned to socialist-oriented market economy. Maintained Communist Party control while liberalizing economy. Set model for other communist countries.

description: Twenty years after war's end, the United States and Vietnam normalized diplomatic relations. President Clinton announced full normalization on July 11, 1995. title: Vietnam Joins WTO - Global Economic Integration

description: Vietnam became the 150th member of the World Trade Organization after 11 years of negotiations. WTO accession required Vietnam to open markets, reduce tariffs, reform laws, and meet international standards. Membership accelerated foreign investment, boosted exports, and integrated Vietnam deeply into global economy. Vietnam became a major manufacturing hub, particularly for electronics, textiles, and furniture. Trade expanded dramatically, transforming Vietnam into one of the world's most open economies.

Proved communist country could thrive in global capitalism. By 2020s, trade over 200% of GDP.

title: South China Sea Disputes - Sovereignty Tensions
titleVietnamese: Tranh chấp Biển Đông - Căng thẳng chủ quyền
description: Vietnam faces ongoing territorial disputes with China over the Paracel and Spratly Islands in the South China Sea (which Vietnam calls the East Sea). China claims most of the sea based on its 'nine-dash line,' building artificial islands with military facilities. Vietnam, along with other ASEAN nations, contests these claims. Tensions include oil rig standoffs, fishing boat harassment, and naval confrontations. The disputes involve sovereignty, fishing rights, oil/gas resources, and strategic sea lanes. International arbitration ruled against China in 2016, but China ignores the ruling.

shortDescription: Ongoing sovereignty disputes with China over islands, resources, and strategic waterways
significance: Major security challenge for Vietnam. China's expansionism threatens sovereignty. Critical for fishing and oil/gas resources. $3+ trillion in trade passes through annually. Strategic importance for Vietnam's security. Drives Vietnam closer to US, Japan. Tests ASEAN unity. Risk of military conflict. Vietnam modernizing navy and coast guard. International support for Vietnam's position. China ignores international law.

title: Vietnam's COVID-19 Response - From Success to Struggle
titleVietnamese: Ứng phó COVID-19 - Từ thành công đến khó khăn
description: Vietnam's pandemic response evolved from global success story to major challenge. Early 2020: Aggressive border controls, quarantine, contact tracing kept infections near zero with minimal deaths. International praise for handling. Mid-2021: Delta variant outbreak overwhelmed defenses. Ho Chi Minh City experienced major outbreak. Strict lockdowns caused economic pain. Late 2021: Shifted to 'living with COVID' approach. Accelerated vaccination. Economy reopened. By 2022: High vaccination rates, life returned to normal, economic recovery underway.
descriptionVietnamese: Việt Nam từ câu chuyện thành công chống dịch đầu 2020 với số ca nhiễm gần như bằng 0, đến khó khăn với biến chủng Delta 2021. Chuyển sang chiến lược 'sống chung với COVID', tăng tốc tiêm chủng, phục hồi kinh tế.
shortDescription: Pandemic response evolved from early success to Delta struggle to vaccination and recovery
significance: Early success demonstrated state capacity. Strict measures kept deaths low initially. Delta outbreak 2021 exposed vulnerabilities. Economic damage from lockdowns. Accelerated digitalization and e-commerce. Vaccination campaign reached 90%+ rates. Showed resilience and adaptation. Economic recovery faster than many nations. Supply chains disrupted but recovered. Tested governance during crisis.

title: Contemporary Vietnam - Emerging Middle Power
titleVietnamese: Việt Nam đương đại - Cường quốc mới nổi
description: By the 2020s, Vietnam has emerged as a dynamic middle power in Southeast Asia. Population of 100 million, GDP approaching $500 billion. One of world's fastest-growing economies with 7%+ annual growth. Major manufacturing hub for global brands. Rising middle class of 50+ million.
